data.title: apm is missing
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

i accidentally uninstalled apm and so i reinstalled atom while i moved all my globaly insalled packages to a local user folder and changed the npm prefix `npm config set prefix .local/share/npm`.

so i simply did `pacman -S atom` to reinstall atom but apm is still nowhere to be found

### Versions

1.16.0

**ps.: is this the right place for this issue?**

data.title: Cannot pitch zoom under the edit area without scrolling
data.body:

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

### Description

I cannot pinch zoom under the `edit` area without scrolling

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a file
2. Type some code
3. And than try pinch zoom under `edit` area

**Expected behavior:** It should be zoom in(or out) without scrolling the whole edit area.

**Actual behavior:** 

![zoom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20783502/25043660/270e8a6e-2154-11e7-8731-61f16f5ab388.gif)

### Versions

`OS`: `macOS sierra`

data.title: Ensure that dock toggle affordances can always be revealed
data.body:
This fixes #14202 by (1) showing the affordance when you mouse out of the window and (2) making sure that the collapsed docks still have a pixel-wide hover area so the affordance can still be shown when the window's fullscreened.

cc @nathansobo @maxbrunsfeld @simurai

data.title: After collapsing a dock, unable to expand dock again
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After collapsing a dock, unable to expand dock again


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom (atom-beta) with a project
2. collapse the tree view by clicking on the arrow.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5624870/25025269/6117cae4-2056-11e7-8e13-15a8e30e7f82.png)

3. hover over where the arrow should be to expand the dock

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
arrow should pop up and let you expand the dock

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
no arrow appears which makes it so you can't expand the dock.  The only way around this is if you drag something and put something in the dock.


**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions
Atom    : 1.17.0-beta1
Electron: 1.3.14
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0


You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

/cc @matthewwithanm

data.title: Dock items are allowed to be reopened with cmd-shift-t
data.body:
### Description

When you focus a dock item and press cmd-w to close it and then cmd-shift-t to re-open it, it does  not open correctly.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Click and focus the tree view
2. Close with cmd-w
3. Reopen with cmd-shift-t

### Versions

I have confirmed this behavior on Atom v1.17-beta0 and v1.17-beta1

### Additional Information

Here's a gif showing the bug in action (Apologize for the low quality, internet uploads are rather slow today)

![kapture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4278113/25021927/6414f3f0-20ad-11e7-9dc0-659c953561dc.gif)

data.title: Use react-native instead of electron?
data.body:
Read this: https://josephg.com/blog/electron-is-flash-for-the-desktop/

I'd be interested in seeing Atom use [React Native](https://github.com/facebook/react-native) if it meant lower strain on system resources.

You would use [react-native-macos](https://github.com/ptmt/react-native-macos) and [react-native-windows](https://github.com/Microsoft/react-native-windows) to target those specific operating systems.

This could be done as a "full rewrite" using [React](https://github.com/facebook/react) to render the UI, but it might be preferred to keep using Atom's current rendering strategy. This would mean using Apple's JavascriptCore and Microsoft's ChakraCore instead of Electron (which installs a copy of Chrome VM for every dependent application). In the end, Atom could still take advantage of React Native's glue code between Javascript and the native OS, regardless of whether React is used to render the UI. Though switching to React may prove to be "easier", but I'm not entirely sure.

I realize this would be a long-term effort, but I think starting a discussion weighing the pros & cons of such a task would be beneficial to the Electron community.

data.title: when closing files with keyboard dock panes close instead.
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When closing files with the keyboard sometimes dock items are closed.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. open an editor and make sure the tree view is in the left dock.
2. open more than one file.
3. close the file with the keyboard shortcut for close file (<kbd>cmd</kbd>-<kbd>W</kbd> on a mac)
4. do the command again.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

The next open file in the center pane will close

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

The tree view itself closes.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

1.17.0
10.12.4

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Window tabs and file tabs overlap with hidden title bar enabled on MacOS
data.body: ### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description With the new `hidden` title bar enabled, MacOS' native window tabs appear on top of Atom's file tabs rather than above them. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Enable `hidden` title bar. 2. Relaunch Atom. 3. Open multiple windows. **Expected behavior:** Window tabs appear above file tabs. **Actual behavior:** Window tabs overlap file tabs. **Reproduces how often:** Always. ### Versions ``` Atom : 1.16.0 Electron: 1.3.13 Chrome : 52.0.2743.82 Node : 6.5.0 apm 1.16.1 npm 3.10.5 node 6.9.5 x64 python 2.7.13 git 2.11.0 MacOS 10.12.4 ``` ### Additional Information Problem occurs across all UI and syntax themes.

data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode

### Description

I am using Atom on a Kubuntu 16.04, unfortunetly Atom can seem to be able to be open in several activities on KDE.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom in one activty
2. Create a new activity
3. Open Atom in the new activity

**Expected behavior:**

Atom should open in the new activity.

**Actual behavior:**

Atom open in the first activity.

**Reproduces how often:**

100%

### Versions

`atom --version`:
```
Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```
`apm --version` :
```
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
```

I am using a kubuntu 16.04.

data.title: Treeview is unusable with Atom 1.16.0
data.body:
### Description

The tree view became unresponsive in Atom 1.16.0.
Can't expand/collapse folders, can't open files.
It does nothing when trying to click on files to open it.

See example video: https://streamable.com/56mqp

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom 1.16.0
2. Open folder / files using the tree view.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
Mac OS X El Capitan: 10.11.6

data.title: Require `TextEditorElement` eagerly
data.body:
Fixes #14193.

With snapshots, all the forbidden modules are required lazily. In the case of `TextEditorElement` this can be problematic because users might create editors via `document.createElement('atom-text-editor')` before we have the chance to register the custom element.

With this pull request we will eagerly require `src/text-editor-element.coffee`, thus forcing `TextEditorElement` to register the HTML custom element when Atom is loaded and fixing the aforementioned issue.

/cc: @atom/maintainers

data.title: "element.getModel" is not a function when no view has been opened yet.
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Hey Atomizers! I just upgraded my version of Atom to 1.17.0-beta0, and I'm having a little trouble with several packages. Since I'm not sure if the behavior reflects an intentional change to Atom's API or not, I wanted to confirm before filing issues with the individual developers.

The issue seems to be that before an editor view has been opened, the function `getModel` is not defined on editor elements. This causes crashes in a number of packages that rely on `atom-space-pen-views` (I think [`text-editor-view.coffee:24`](https://github.com/atom/atom-space-pen-views/blob/master/src/text-editor-view.coffee#L24) is the problem line), and at least one ([`foldingtext-for-atom`](https://github.com/FoldingText/foldingtext-for-atom)) that does not. For example, I normally open a fresh window with "Empty Editor On Start" disabled, invoke the Project Manager package, pick a project, and do my business; now, since I haven't opened a tab yet, pulling up Project Manager throws an error like this one:

```
At /Users/daniel/.atom/packages/project-manager/node_modules/atom-space-pen-views/lib/text-editor-view.js:40

TypeError: this.element.getModel is not a function
    at /packages/project-manager/node_modules/atom-space-pen-views/lib/text-editor-view.js:40:34)
    at Object.content (/packages/project-manager/node_modules/atom-space-pen-views/lib/select-list-view.js:26:45)
    at Builder.tag (/packages/project-manager/node_modules/space-pen/lib/space-pen.js:281:19)
    at /packages/project-manager/node_modules/space-pen/lib/space-pen.js:83:49)
    at Function.module.exports.SelectListView.content (/packages/project-manager/node_modules/atom-space-pen-views/lib/select-list-view.js:22:19)
    at /packages/project-manager/node_modules/space-pen/lib/space-pen.js:156:31)
    at Function.View.buildHtml (/packages/project-manager/node_modules/space-pen/lib/space-pen.js:123:10)
    at /packages/project-manager/node_modules/space-pen/lib/space-pen.js:155:33)
    at /packages/project-manager/node_modules/atom-space-pen-views/lib/select-list-view.js:18:51)
    at /packages/project-manager/lib/views/projects-list-view.js:10:38)
    at /packages/project-manager/lib/project-manager.js:34:28)
    at CommandRegistry.module.exports.CommandRegistry.handleCommandEvent (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/command-registry.js:265:1)
    at /Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/command-registry.js:3:1
    at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.dispatchCommandEvent (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:610:1)
    at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.handleKeyboardEvent (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:401:1)
    at WindowEventHandler.module.exports.WindowEventHandler.handleDocumentKeyEvent (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/window-event-handler.js:100:1)
    at HTMLDocument.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/window-event-handler.js:3:1)
```

With FoldingText installed at all, opening a new Atom window throws this:

```
At /Users/daniel/.atom/packages/foldingtext-for-atom/lib/extensions/ui/text-input-element.coffee:19

TypeError: this.textEditorElement.getModel is not a function
    at /packages/foldingtext-for-atom/lib/extensions/ui/text-input-element.coffee:19:38)
    at Object.exports.consumeStatusBarService (/packages/foldingtext-for-atom/lib/extensions/search-status-bar-item.coffee:9:28)
    at Object.addStatusBarItemsIfReady (/packages/foldingtext-for-atom/lib/foldingtext.coffee:139:53)
    at Object.consumeStatusBarService (/packages/foldingtext-for-atom/lib/foldingtext.coffee:130:6)
    at Provider.module.exports.Provider.provide (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/service-hub/lib/provider.js:34:1)
    at ServiceHub.module.exports.ServiceHub.provide (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/service-hub/lib/service-hub.js:30:1)
    at Package.module.exports.Package.activateServices (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/package.js:446:1)
    at Package.module.exports.Package.activateNow (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/package.js:256:1)
    at /Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/package.js:225:1
    at Package.module.exports.Package.measure (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/package.js:99:1)
    at /Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/package.js:218:1
    at Package.module.exports.Package.activate (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/package.js:215:1)
    at PackageManager.module.exports.PackageManager.activatePackage (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/package-manager.js:642:1)
    at /Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/package-manager.js:623:1
    at Config.module.exports.Config.transactAsync (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/config.js:346:1)
    at PackageManager.module.exports.PackageManager.activatePackages (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/package-manager.js:618:1)
    at PackageManager.module.exports.PackageManager.activate (/Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/package-manager.js:600:1)
    at /Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/atom-environment.js:831:1
```

For the moment, uninstalling FoldingText and reenabling "Empty Editor On Start" seems to be a serviceable workaround. It'd be great to see an actual fix for this, though.

![screenflow](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2207980/24997961/7f29a002-2006-11e7-9110-9b9527e995b9.gif)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install any package that depends on `atom-space-pen-views`---try e.g. Project Manager, it's lovely.
2. With "Open Empty Editor On Start" disabled, open a new Atom window.
3. Run your sample package before opening an editor view.
4. 💥 

**Expected behavior:** The package should run without crashing.

**Actual behavior:** The package crashes.

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time before an editor view has been created.

### Versions

**Atom**: 1.17.0-beta0 x64
**Electron**: 1.3.14
**OS**: Mac OS X 10.12.4

### Additional Information

💖

data.title: Issue building Atom on Ubuntu 16.04 - cannot find scrollbar-style-observer
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I am trying to build atom from source on Ubuntu 16.04 and it builds without issue, however upon running the atom binary, I am presented with a grey screen and the following error:

    Uncaught Error: Cannot find module '../build/Release/scrollbar-style-observer.node'

I have:
 - Tried cleaning the build: `script/clean`
 - Tried cleaning the NPM cache: `rm -rf ~/.npm && npm cache clear`
 - Deleted my local git repo and started again
 - Tried safe mode

### Steps to Reproduce

1. script/clean
2. script/build

**Expected behavior:** Atom opens as per usual

**Actual behavior:** Atom presents me with a completely grey screen. Developer console gives me the above error.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time I open atom, even after a new build.

### Versions
    atom --version
    Atom    : 1.18.0-dev-f4fceb0
    Electron: 1.3.14
    Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
    Node    : 6.5.0
    
    apm --version
    apm  1.17.0
    npm  3.10.5
    node 6.9.5 x64
    python 2.7.12
    git 2.7.4
    
    uname -a
    Linux ProgrammerWS 4.4.0-66-generic #87-Ubuntu SMP Fri Mar 3 15:29:05 UTC 2017 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
    
    cat /etc/issue
    Ubuntu 16.04 LTS \n \l

data.title: File dialogues broken
data.body: ### Prerequisites * [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description Neither `File/Reopen Project` nor `File/Add Project Folder` work if the main Atom window has been closed. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Launch Atom 2. Select `File/Reopen Project` or `File/Add Project Folder` 3. **Expected behavior:** In `step 3` above I expect either Atom to open with my project or to be presented with a file dialogue. **Actual behavior:** Nothing happens when selecting `File/Reopen Project` or `File/Add Project Folder` if the empty Atom window is closed. **Reproduces how often:** 100% ### Versions > brandons-mbp:~ Brandon$ atom --version Atom : 1.15.0 Electron: 1.3.13 Chrome : 52.0.2743.82 Node : 6.5.0 ### Additional Information Occurs in both Atom and Atom Beta on macOS 10.12.x.

data.title: Closing developer tools focuses go-to-line
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When closing the developer tools, the go-to-line status bar component receives focus instead of what previously had focus.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a folder (this appears to be necessary) and a file
2. Open the developer tools
3. Close the developer tools

**Expected behavior:** Editor to receive focus

**Actual behavior:** go-to-line in the status bar receives focus

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.18.0-dev-8eaafc23c
Electron: 1.6.5
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```
```
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.12.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

data.title: onDidReload getting fired before onDidChange
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
onDidReload getting fired before onDidChange

### Steps to Reproduce
Was able to get a isolated repro with @Arcanemagus help.

1. `git clone https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint.git`
2. `git checkout arcanemagus/atom-repro-case`
3. run `atom .` from the repo cloned in step 1.
4. run package specs(test will always pass)
5.  open devtools in the spec window


**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
onDidReload gets fired after onDidChange.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
`onDidReload` sometimes gets fired before `onDidChange`,  This causes issues as `onDidReload` is being fired when the editor is blank.  

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
~75%


### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.
Atom    : 1.18.0-dev-9202160ca
Electron: 1.3.14
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information
Here's a screenshot of the issue you'll see after you open dev tools

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5624870/24980007/3b5fae46-1f8b-11e7-9911-7f4beceeeea2.png)

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.


This is probably the underlying cause for issues #12243 and #5730

data.title: Always search a pane container w/ the given URI in workspace.open
data.body: Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14184

data.title: Renaming an open file and then saving it recreates the file with the original filename
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When you rename a file opened in atom using tree view or right click on the tab, the file is renamed but the file name of the opened file is not updated.
At the end:
- if you continue editing and save, you edited the wrong file and re-created a file with the original name
- if you close the tab without editing, atom if you want to save your work

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a file named "file1"
2. Add some text and save
3. Rename by right-clicking on the tab > rename to "file2"
4a. close the tab -> atom asks to save the file. choosing yes will create a file named "file1"
4b. add some text and press Ctrl+S -> will create a file named "file1" with the updated content. "file2" will be the old state of "file1"

**Expected behavior:** Rename action shoud be picked up by the editor and the open file should be the "new" one

**Actual behavior:** Only moves the file but atom ignores it

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Debian Stretch
Atom 1.15 x64
Blank atom state (.atom directory removed before testing)

data.title: resizing window with docks doesn't resize proportionally
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

resizing window with docks doesn't resize proportionally 

### Steps to Reproduce (this is easier to repro on windows than mac)

1.  Open a project in atom
2. Open two files
3. move one of the files to the bottom dock or the right dock
4. make the dock that you moved the file to fill half of the screen
5. Resize Atom to be smaller

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
The docks are resize proportional to the window that is resized.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
The Dock takes up the entire window, hiding the center dock.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%
### Versions
```
Atom    : 1.17.0-dev-3292e3b4d
Electron: 1.3.14
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```
You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information
NOTE: will update screenshot 

![resize](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5624870/24969417/9b22c366-1f65-11e7-8982-6f90b485551a.gif)


Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: File re-tokenizes when clicked in the Tree View
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When attempting to open an already-open file through the Tree View, the file is re-tokenized, leading to a brief flash of unstyled content.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a file
2. Click the file again (slowly, as to not reproduce #14184)

**Expected behavior:** No re-tokenization to occur

**Actual behavior:** The file re-tokenizes

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.18.0-dev-e8ae30217
Electron: 1.6.5
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```
```
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.12.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

### Additional Information

![file-retokenization](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/24967088/f3ae5f5c-1f76-11e7-887a-fb7ee208a243.gif)
(Note: due to the low framerate of the GIF, some of the flashes weren't captured)

Related to #14184

/cc: @nathansobo

data.title: Duplicate tabs can be opened
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When opening files (eg from the Tree View, which is where I experienced this), it is possible to open the same file multiple times.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Rapidly double-click on the same file in the Tree View

**Expected behavior:** The file to open once, become permanent (if applicable), and further double-clicks on the file to refocus the editor.

**Actual behavior:** The file opens multiple times.

**Reproduces how often:** Almost 100%.  @nathansobo mentioned that it's more likely to occur the faster you click, probably because of the new async methods.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.18.0-dev-e8ae30217
Electron: 1.6.5
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```
```
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.12.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

### Additional Information

![multiple-files](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/24919739/a16fc5ba-1eb2-11e7-846d-eeeed3a46472.gif)

/cc: @nathansobo @maxbrunsfeld @matthewwithanm

data.title: Properly restore focus to center when hiding dock via toggle
data.body:
Previously, we were only restoring focus to the active center pane when hiding a dock via the *hide* method. Since `toggle` calls `setState` directly, we weren't notifying the workspace and restoring focus when hiding the dock via `toggle`. This PR fixes that.

@maxbrunsfeld we should cherry-pick this to 1.17-releases before publishing today.

data.title: [keyboard shortcuts] can't use assigned `ctrl-shift-[` / `ctrl-shift-]`
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
* [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
* [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
* [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
* [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

keyboard shortcuts: can't use assigned `ctrl-shift-[` / `ctrl-shift-]`

### Steps to Reproduce

1. in `keymap.cson` put
``` cson
'body':
  'cmd-shift-[': 'pane:show-previous-item'
  'cmd-shift-]': 'pane:show-next-item'
  'ctrl-shift-[': 'pane:show-previous-item'
  'ctrl-shift-]': 'pane:show-next-item'
```
2. try to use any of those

**Expected behavior:** 

assigned shortcuts work as intended

**Actual behavior:** 
- `ctrl-shift-[` -- nothing happens
- `cmd-shift-[` -- outputs `{`

**Reproduces how often:** always

### Versions
#### OS:
- Ubuntu 16.10

#### Atom:
- Atom    : 1.15.0
- Electron: 1.3.13
- Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
- Node    : 6.5.0

#### APM:
- apm:  1.15.3
- npm:  3.10.5
- node: 4.4.5 x64
- python: 2.7.12
- git: 2.7.4

### Additional information:

tried assign `ctrl-shift-{` -- same thing
